Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Internal Decay and Carbon Loss in Living Trees
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Early concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) will develop a new and potentially powerful approach to determining the extent and rate of internal decay in living trees, without having to cut them down. Two portable versions of equipment similar to CAT scanners will be used to create images of stem cross-sections. These images will be used to estimate the total amount of carbon lost to decay over the lifetime of the tree. The project will focus on the three principal northern hardwood species: sugar maple, yellow birch, and American beech.

This project will involve the collaboration of two forest pathologists who have complementary backgrounds and expertise in forestry, forest ecology and mycology. Two student interns from the Stockbridge School of Agriculture Internship program will be trained. The lead scientists have responsibilities for public outreach and will extend results to forest ecologists, arborists and urban foresters. Data will contribute to the development of forest management strategies aimed at mitigating the effects of increased atmospheric carbon dioxide. Results will also be used in displays and presentations at local science museums, schools and public events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principle goal of this project was to develop, through testing and validation, a novel methodology for the nondestructive quantification of both extent and rate of internal decay in living trees. This methodology has the potential to facilitate research that will transform current understanding of the role of forests in mitigating against climate change and global warming. Results of the current project demonstrate conclusively that cavities and decay in trees can be accurately predicted using sonic and electrical resistance tomographies (SoT and ERT, respectively). SoT and ERT measure the movement of sound waves and electrical current, respectively, through a tree, generating cross-sectional images that correlate to variations in density and electrical conductivity. 

The field component of this project took place at Great Mountain Forest in Norfolk, Connecticut, in the summer of 2014. With a focus on the three principle northern hardwoods—American Beech, Sugar Maple, and Yellow Birch—over 20 trees of each species were analyzed at three or more cross-sections using both SoT and ERT (Figures 1, 2). Subsequently, a majority of these trees were felled, and cross-sections (“cookies”) cut at the point of tomographic measurement.

The laboratory component of the project took place in the winter of 2014-2015. Cookies were planed and sanded in preparation for sampling and photography (Figures 3, 4). Photographs confirmed the accuracy of tomography in identifying irregularities such as decay and cavities (Figure 5). Cookies were also used to estimate tree ages, which ranged from approximately 66 to 190 years old. Wood samples assayed for carbon content showed that variation depicted in sonic tomographs correlates to variation in carbon density.

The most important conclusion to be drawn from this project is that sonic and electrical resistance tomography constitute a powerful tool for nondestructively quantifying internal decay in living trees (Figure 6). The methodology distinguishes intact non-decayed wood from cavities and areas of active decay, and also facilitates an estimation of their volumes, which enables estimation of the amount (absolute and relative) of carbon lost to decay.  Combined with an estimate of the tree’s age, a lifetime rate of carbon loss can thus be estimated. 

This project, representing the successful collaborative efforts of two forest pathologists and a forest ecologist with expertise in dendrochronology, provided important training in forestry, forest pathology, and dendrochronology to two student interns, a research technician, and a research intern. Additionally, tomographic demonstrations have provided opportunities for outreach on the potential of this technology in arboriculture and forestry research. Formal presentations on the research project have reached a broad audience ranging from the general public, forest and land care professionals to the scientific community.
